comment._content:
Herbert Martin Benson Lawford, b. 1887, was the son of Martin Benson Lawford and Emily Agnes Lawford, (nee St George, from Birkenhead), of Trewern, Oswestry, Shropshire. He was commissioned into the infantry as a Temporary Second Lieutenant on 26th September 1914, [LG 29 Sep 1914]. 

9th Battalion Royal Fusiliers (City of London Regiment) was in 18th (Eastern) Division involved in the attacks in October 1916 on the stubbornly defended and vital position of and around the Schwaben Redoubt. On 7th October there was a determined counter-attack by the Germans to recapture the Redoubt.//

comment._content: Herbert Martin Benson Lawford was born in Oswestry in 1887. The family may have been living at 28 Upper Brook Street, Oswestry in 1891 (census is very faded). The building is Grade II listed www.britishlistedbuildings.co.uk/en-255582-26-and-28-uppe.... Mr Lawford was a Solicitor and employed a Cook, a Nurse and a House Maid

comment.author: 64288588@N05
comment._content:
In 1901 HMBL was a Boarder at Winchester School. 
1911 census had him at Iver Villa, Furzeham Road, West Drayton, Shropshire and he was working as a Solicitor's Articled Clerk.
National Probate Calendar gave his address of Trewern, Oswestry (his parents' address) and probate was granted to his father 4 July 1917. Effects £3069 10s 4d.

comment.author: 64288588@N05
comment._content: London Gazettee 29 September 1914 has the following: The following to be Second Lieutenants. Dated 26th September, 1914:— Herbert Martin Benson Lawford. www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/28918/pages/7691/page.pdf A family member posted on 1914-1918.invisionzone.com/forums/index.php?showtopic=17686 and received the following information: From the date of death and the battalion it is likely that Captain Lawford would have been KIA in the attack on Bayonet Trench north of Guedecourt/Flers. The following is an extract from Westlakes' 'Battalions on the Somme' 9th (Service) Battalion. 36th Brigade, 12th (Eastern) Division: Moved from billets at Frechencourt to Nab trenches in support (1/7). To line at Ovillers (5/7). Heavy losses during attack on Ovillers (7/7). To Senlis (9/7), Forceville (10/7), Bus-les-Artois (11/7), Mailly-Maillet (20/7), Bois de Warnimont (24/7) , Bus-les-Artois (25/7), Hedauville (26/7), Bouzincourt (27/7), Albert (29/7). Successful attacks on 4th Avenue and Ration Trenches (3/8) and (4/8). To Varennes (9/8), Puchevillers via Lealvillers and Toutencourt (12/8), Vauchelles-les-Authie (I5/8). Transferred to Arras sector ( 16/8). Arrived Neuvillette (28/9). To Pommiers Redoubt (30/9), trenches west of Gueudecourt (6/10). To Gird support line (7/10) - heavy losses during attack on Bayonet Trench, To Bernafay Wood (8/10), front line Gueudecourt (16/10), Fricourt Camp (19/10), Burie (20/10). Transferred to Arras sector (22/10). The Law Society's records show that Captain Lawford was a solicitor, having been admitted in October 1911. He was a member of Longueville & Co., of Oswestry. Information, obtained (presumably) from his family in 1920s is as follows: He obtained a commission in Royal Fusiliers at the outbreak of War and promoted Captain June 1915. Wounded March 1916 and returned to front in September 1916. Reported missing 7th October 1916 and subsequently officially reported killed in action that day.
